Knowledge Point: The minimal constituents of an \isi{intransitive} clause are a subject (S) and a verb (V); a \isi{transitive} clause consists of these two elements as well as an object (O). Stated in terms more agnostic with respect to notions of subjecthood and objecthood, an \isi{intransitive} clause consists of a single argument (S) and a verb (V), whereas a \isi{transitive} clause consists of a more \isi{agent}-like argument (A), a more \isi{patient}-like argument (P), and a verb (V). The basic ordering of these elements is given in \REF{ex:clause:1}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Although various \isi{pragmatic} factors may affect the ordering (or overt expression) of elements in a clause, Ulwa nevertheless has a fairly rigid ordering of constituents. The order presented in \REF{ex:clause:1} is used for essentially all \isi{active-voice} clauses. In the \isi{intransitive} clauses presented in \REF{ex:clause:2} through \REF{ex:clause:6}, the subject is in \textbf{bold}. The verb is always the final element of the clause.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Alum mï} sap. | \gll \textbf{alum} \textbf{mï} sa-p | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ cry-PFV | \glt `The baby cried.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Alum} uleplïnda. | \gll \textbf{alum} ulep-lï-nda | \gls child jump-put-IRR | \glt `The child will jump.’

Knowledge Point: In the \isi{transitive} clauses given in \REF{ex:clause:7}, \REF{ex:clause:8}, and \REF{ex:clause:9}, the subject (or more \isi{agent}ive participant) is in \textbf{bold}, and the object (or more \isi{patient}ive participant) is underlined. The verb is always the final element of the clause.\footnote{Note that \isi{object-marker} \isi{clitic}s have been underlined in examples \REF{ex:clause:8} and \REF{ex:clause:9}, although they \isi{clitic}ize to the following verb. See \sectref{sec:7.2} for more on \isi{object marker}s and \sectref{sec:9.2} for a discussion of their \isi{syntactic} place within the \isi{verb phrase}.}
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Itom mï} uta walinda. | \gll \textbf{itom} \textbf{mï} uta wali-nda | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ bird hit-IRR | \glt `Father will shoot a bird.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Alimban mï} apa mayte. | \gll \textbf{Alimban} \textbf{mï} apa ma=ita-e | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ house 3SG.OBJ=build-IPFV | \glt `Alimban is building the house.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Apa mï} alum masap. | \gll \textbf{apa} \textbf{mï} alum ma=asa-p | \gls house 3SG.SUBJ child 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `The house killed the child.’
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Alimban mï} apa mayte. | \gll \textbf{Alimban} \textbf{mï} apa ma=ita-e | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ house 3SG.OBJ=build-IPFV | \glt `Alimban is building the house.’
Content 5: \gsrc \textbf{Apa mï} alum masap. | \gll \textbf{apa} \textbf{mï} alum ma=asa-p | \gls house 3SG.SUBJ child 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `The house killed the child.’

Knowledge Point: As is suggested by example \REF{ex:clause:9}, in which the subject/\isi{agent} is \isi{inanimate} and the object/\isi{patient} is \isi{animate}, notions of \isi{agent}ivity or \isi{patient}ivity are not intrinsic to NPs based on their referents. That is, principles such as the \isi{animacy hierarchy} \label{ref:RNDui1Xjf4uVA}\citep{Silverstein1976} play no role in determining \isi{constituent order} (or \isi{core argument alignment}, \sectref{sec:11.2}) in Ulwa.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Apa mï} alum masap. | \gll \textbf{apa} \textbf{mï} alum ma=asa-p | \gls house 3SG.SUBJ child 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `The house killed the child.’

Knowledge Point: This S(O)V order is rigid for most clause types. However, it is possible for the subject (S) constituent to be omitted when its referent is clear from context. Ulwa may thus be considered a \isi{pro-drop} language. However, while subjects may be omitted, it is not common for objects to be omitted: a \isi{transitive} clause generally must, at the very least, contain an \isi{object marker} \isi{proclitic}. Sentences \REF{ex:clause:10} through \REF{ex:clause:20} illustrate sentences with unexpressed subjects.
Content 1: \gsrc Wop. | \gll wo-p | \gls sleep-PFV | \glt `[He] slept.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ko angwena man inim atïna ne? | \gll ko angwena ma=n inim atï-na na-i | \gls just why 3SG.OBJ=OBL water hit-IRR DETR-go.PFV | \glt `Why did [you] just go to throw it in the water?’

Knowledge Point: Sometimes, in \isi{transitive} clauses, emphasis can be placed on an object by fronting it to the beginning of the clause. Even in such instances, however, the order of the clause (following this arguably preclausal element) is usually still SOV, since the referent of the fronted object invariably appears again in the clause, marked by an \isi{agreement} marker immediately preceding the verb, as in examples \REF{ex:clause:21} through \REF{ex:clause:24}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji alum ndï} nï Wopata ndape \textbf{ndinap}. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} \textbf{alum} \textbf{ndï} nï Wopata anda=p-e \textbf{ndï=}ina-p | \gls 1SG-POSS child 3PL 1SG [place] SG.DIST=be{-dep} 3PL=get-PFV | \glt `My children -- I had them when I was there at Wopata.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji yenat ngala} nï nan \textbf{ndït}: … | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} \textbf{yenat} \textbf{ngala} nï na=n \textbf{ndï}=ta | \gls 1SG-POSS daughter PL.PROX 1SG talk=OBL 3PL=say | \glt `My daughters -- I told them: …’

Knowledge Point: The three basic core arguments of all clause types may be considered to be S, A, and P \REF{ex:clause:24a}.\footnote{P is also sometimes identified as O in the literature.}
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: S and A occur in the same position in the clause (namely, clause-initially), whereas P occurs after S and before the verb. Since there is no \is{core argument} core-argument \isi{case morphology} in Ulwa, it is generally fruitless to talk about “\isi{nominative}” and “\isi{accusative}” or “\isi{ergative}” and “\isi{absolutive}” NPs in Ulwa (at least in terms of \isi{morphological} marking). There is, however, one important distinction found in 3\textsc{sg} \isi{pronoun}s and \isi{determiner}s (i.e., \isi{subject marker}s and \isi{object marker}s). Whereas the 3\textsc{sg} subject form is /mï/, the 3\textsc{sg} object form is /ma=/ \REF{ex:clause:24b}. The fact that third-\isi{singular} S and A NPs are both marked with mï ‘3\textsc{sg.subj}’, whereas third-\isi{singular} P NPs are marked with ma= ‘3\textsc{sg.obj}’ is further indication of \isi{accusative alignment}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Finally, there is no evidence of Ulwa exhibiting \isi{syntactic ergativity} (\citealt[62--63]{Dixon1979}). Thus, for example, in \isi{coordinate} constructions (\sectref{sec:12.1}), coreference is possible between S and A but not between S and P. In \REF{ex:clause:25}, the omitted S argument of the second clause must be understood to refer to the stated A argument (yana ‘woman’) of the first clause.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Similarly, in sentence \REF{ex:clause:26}, the A argument Kolpe must be understood to be the omitted S argument of the second clause, and it would be impossible for the P argument mana ‘spear’ to be understood as such.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: There is also no indication of \isi{split-intransitivity} or related \isi{alignment} types in the language (i.e., there is no active-stative/semantic/\isi{fluid alignment} in Ulwa), nor is there any sign of \isi{direct-inverse alignment} based on \is{animacy hierarchy} animacy or any other \isi{hierarchy}. That is, all types of S arguments pattern more closely with A arguments than with P arguments, regardless of \isi{semantics} or other criteria. Thus, S arguments of clauses are alike both \isi{syntactic}ally and \isi{morphological}ly, irrespective of whether they are more \isi{agent}ive (i.e., \isi{unergative}) \REF{ex:clause:27} or more \isi{patient}ive (i.e., \isi{unaccusative}) \REF{ex:clause:28}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alum mï uleplïp. | \gll alum mï ulep-lï-p | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ jump-put-PFV | \glt `The child jumped.’
Content 2: \gsrc Alum mï liyu. | \gll alum mï li-u | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ down-put | \glt `The child fell.’

Knowledge Point: This universal treatment of S arguments holds for all NPs, whether full NPs, as in \REF{ex:clause:27} and \REF{ex:clause:28}, or pronominal NPs, as in \REF{ex:clause:29} and \REF{ex:clause:30}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alum mï uleplïp. | \gll alum mï ulep-lï-p | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ jump-put-PFV | \glt `The child jumped.’
Content 2: \gsrc Alum mï liyu. | \gll alum mï li-u | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ down-put | \glt `The child fell.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï amun natan. | \gll nï amun na-ta-n | \gls 1SG now DETR-say-IPFV | \glt `I am speaking now.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nï amun kïkalwana. | \gll nï amun kïkal-wana | \gls 1SG now ear-feel | \glt `I am listening now.’

Knowledge Point: As well as considering the \isi{morphosyntactic} patterning of S, A, and P arguments, some typologists analyze the relationships among arguments in \isi{ditransitive} constructions. Typological endeavors such as \citet{MalchukovEtAl2010} have largely focused on \isi{dative construction}s -- that is, constructions in which something is given from one participant to another. In some languages, these constructions make use of \isi{ditransitive} verbs, which take three arguments: A, R, and T \REF{ex:clause:30a}. The question of interest is whether the P argument of a \isi{monotransitive} verb patterns more like the R argument or the T argument of a \isi{ditransitive} verb (it is not ever known to pattern like the A argument).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In Ulwa, however, there are no \isi{ditransitive} verbs. In short, there is no word ‘give’ in the sense of \ili{English} give, which may, in some uses, be considered \isi{ditransitive} (as in sentences such as John gave Mary a rose). To express ‘giving’ events in Ulwa, two verbs are needed: one verb generally has the meaning ‘take’, and has as its object an NP with a \isi{theme} role (the ‘\isi{gift}’); the other verb is usually na- ‘give’,\footnote{It should be noted that the fact that the (\isi{monotransitive}) verb glossed as ‘give’ has as its (sole) object a \isi{recipient} does not imply any sort of \isi{ditransitive alignment} between R and P arguments. The verb na- ‘give’, despite being glossed for convenience as ‘give’, is not equivalent to the \ili{English} word give. There is, however, unfortunately, no basic \isi{monotransitive} \ili{English} word with which to gloss this \isi{monotransitive} Ulwa word, which means something more like ‘endow’ (although even this \ili{English} gloss is not a very good match, since it can have as its object NP either a \isi{recipient} or a \isi{theme}).} which has as its object an NP with a \isi{recipient} role (the receiver). Sentence \REF{ex:clause:30a} refers to a ‘giving’ event.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Given the nature of real-world scenarios involved in the act of giving, it is common for sentences referring to ‘giving’ events to include three participants: \isi{giver} (\isi{agent}), \isi{recipient} (\isi{benefactive}), and \isi{gift} (\isi{theme}). As such, these three participants are often all expressed in Ulwa ‘giving’ constructions, generally through the use of at least two verbs. It is, however, possible for the verb na- ‘give’ to occur without any other verb encoding the \isi{theme} argument; in such instances, the only two roles expressed (as determined by the verb’s argument structure) are the \isi{giver} (the grammatical subject) and the \isi{recipient} (the grammatical object), as in \REF{ex:clause:31} and \REF{ex:clause:32}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Manata} we mï man ulum ndïnalin. | \gll \textbf{ma=na}-ta we mï ma=n ulum ndï=n ali-n[da] | \gls 3SG.OBJ=give-COND then 3SG.SUBJ 3SG.OBJ=OBL palm 3PL=OBL scrape-IRR | \glt `If [they] give her [it], then she will scrape sago palms with it.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïnane} mane ndï ndame. | \gll \textbf{ndï=na}-n-e ma-n-e ndï ndï=ama-e | \gls 3PL=give-PFV-DEP go-IPFV-DEP 3PL 3PL=eat-IPFV | \glt `Going and giving them, they would eat them.’

Knowledge Point: When the \isi{theme} (\isi{gift}) is also overtly expressed, it is necessary to use another verb. The verb that is most commonly used along with na- ‘give’ in these constructions is the verb tï- ‘take’ (see \sectref{sec:4.3}). This first verb, tï- ‘take’, has as its object the \isi{theme} (that which is given), whereas the second verb, na- ‘give’, has as its object the beneficiary (to whom something is given), as in examples \REF{ex:clause:33} through \REF{ex:clause:40}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alma mï lamndu \textbf{matï} Kongos \textbf{manan}. | \gll Alma mï lamndu ma=\textbf{tï} Kongos ma=\textbf{na}-n | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ pig 3SG.OBJ=take [name] 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV | \glt `Alma gave a pig to Kongos.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï yena \textbf{ndït} \textbf{ndïnane} ndï ndul wop. | \gll ndï yena ndï=\textbf{tï} ndï=\textbf{na}-n-e ndï ndï=ul wo-p | \gls 3PL woman 3PL=take 3PL=give-PFV-DEP 3PL 3PL=with sleep-PFV | \glt `They gave the women to them and they slept with them.’

Knowledge Point: Since the verb tï- ‘take’ is often \isi{defective}, as in most of examples \REF{ex:clause:33} through \REF{ex:clause:40}, it looks very much like these are \isi{separable verb} constructions (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}). However, given the verbal nature of tï- ‘take’, these ‘giving’ constructions can instead be described as a modest form of \isi{serial verb construction}s.\footnote{Although not quite fitting some stricter criteria for \isi{serial verb construction}s \citep[8]{Aikhenvald2006}, since (as a \isi{defective verb}) tï- ‘take’ does not match na- ‘give’ in its \isi{TAM} marking, these Ulwa ‘giving’ constructions qualify as such under definitions such as \citegen[296]{Haspelmath2016}: “a \isi{monoclausal construction} consisting of multiple independent verbs with no element linking them and with no \isi{predicate}-argument relation between the verbs”. That said, when it lacks \isi{TAM} marking, tï- ‘take’ is not clearly finite.} Even if we are to consider these ‘giving’ constructions to be instances of \isi{serial verb construction}s in Ulwa, then verb serialization is certainly not a productive \isi{syntactic} construction -- if it indeed exists in the language, then it is restricted to encoding what might be considered “\isi{ditransitive} events”.
Content 1: \gsrc Alma mï lamndu \textbf{matï} Kongos \textbf{manan}. | \gll Alma mï lamndu ma=\textbf{tï} Kongos ma=\textbf{na}-n | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ pig 3SG.OBJ=take [name] 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV | \glt `Alma gave a pig to Kongos.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï yena \textbf{ndït} \textbf{ndïnane} ndï ndul wop. | \gll ndï yena ndï=\textbf{tï} ndï=\textbf{na}-n-e ndï ndï=ul wo-p | \gls 3PL woman 3PL=take 3PL=give-PFV-DEP 3PL 3PL=with sleep-PFV | \glt `They gave the women to them and they slept with them.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, there are some instances in which it seems best to analyze Ulwa ‘giving’ constructions as consisting of two separate clauses. When the first verb tï- ‘take’ is marked for \isi{TAM}, it must also receive the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ (\sectref{sec:12.2.1}), proving, as it were, that this verb belongs to a separate clause. This may be seen in sentence \REF{ex:clause:41}.
Content 1: \gsrc Uma \textbf{ndïtïne} Wombasame \textbf{manane} mï ndïn ne. | \gll uma ndï=\textbf{tï-n}-e Wombasame ma=\textbf{na-n}-e mï ndï=n ni-e | \gls bone 3PL=take-PFV-DEP [name] 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `[They] gave the bones to Wombasame, and he began playing with them.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:clause:41} may be rendered more literally as: ‘After [they] took the bones, and after [they] gave Wombasame, he was acting with them.’ Finally, it should be said that the instances in which tï- ‘take’ does not receive any \isi{TAM} marking could be considered a very modest form of \isi{clause chaining}, although, if so, then there would be only one \isi{medial clause} involved (see \sectref{sec:12.4} for more on possible \isi{clause-chaining} structures in Ulwa). Furthermore, the fact the tï- ‘take’ is so often \isi{defective} even in monoverbal, \isi{monoclausal sentence}s makes its putative dependence on the “\isi{final verb}” less diagnostic.
Content 1: \gsrc Uma \textbf{ndïtïne} Wombasame \textbf{manane} mï ndïn ne. | \gll uma ndï=\textbf{tï-n}-e Wombasame ma=\textbf{na-n}-e mï ndï=n ni-e | \gls bone 3PL=take-PFV-DEP [name] 3SG.OBJ=give-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `[They] gave the bones to Wombasame, and he began playing with them.’

Knowledge Point: It is possible to form other (multi-verb) ‘giving’ constructions in Ulwa with other (\isi{inflect}ed) verbs that mean ‘take’. In sentences \REF{ex:clause:42} and \REF{ex:clause:43}, the verb moko- ‘take’, which often has the sense ‘take one by one’, is used along with the verb na- ‘give’.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï ani \textbf{ndïmokop} \textbf{ndïnana}. | \gll mï ani ndï=\textbf{moko}-p ndï=\textbf{na}-na | \gls 3SG.SUBJ bilum 3PL=take-PFV 3PL=give-PFV | \glt `He gave them the bilum [= string bags] [one by one].’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndït wa i ndïweyawe \textbf{ndïmoke} lapun \textbf{ndïnane}. | \gll ndï=tï wa i ndï=we-aw-e ndï=\textbf{moko}-e lapun ndï=\textbf{na}-n-e | \gls 3PL=take village go.PFV 3PL=cut-put.IPFV-DEP 3PL=take{-dep} old 3PL=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `[They] used to bring them home, cut them, and give them out to the old people.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:clause:42} could be analyzed as a \isi{serial verb construction} if it is assumed that the two verbs belong to a single clause. Indeed, they even match in terms of \isi{TAM} marking. In example \REF{ex:clause:43}, however, the verb moko- ‘take’ is marked as belonging to a different clause. Moreover, it does not share \isi{TAM} marking with na- ‘give’, suggesting that this is not a \isi{serial verb construction}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï ani \textbf{ndïmokop} \textbf{ndïnana}. | \gll mï ani ndï=\textbf{moko}-p ndï=\textbf{na}-na | \gls 3SG.SUBJ bilum 3PL=take-PFV 3PL=give-PFV | \glt `He gave them the bilum [= string bags] [one by one].’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndït wa i ndïweyawe \textbf{ndïmoke} lapun \textbf{ndïnane}. | \gll ndï=tï wa i ndï=we-aw-e ndï=\textbf{moko}-e lapun ndï=\textbf{na}-n-e | \gls 3PL=take village go.PFV 3PL=cut-put.IPFV-DEP 3PL=take{-dep} old 3PL=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `[They] used to bring them home, cut them, and give them out to the old people.’

Knowledge Point: The combination of moko- ‘take’ and na- ‘give’ is often used to describe the distribution or sharing of items, typically with a \isi{reflexive} object form preceding the verb na- ‘give’, as in \REF{ex:clause:44}, \REF{ex:clause:45}, and \REF{ex:clause:46}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï ndït anmbïlïp \textbf{ndïmoke} \textbf{amblanane}. | \gll ndï ndï=tï an-mbï-lï-p ndï=moko-e \textbf{ambla}=na-n-e | \gls 3PL 3PL=take out-here-put-PFV 3PL=take-DEP PL.REFL=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `They got them out and were sharing them among themselves.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï ilum \textbf{moke} \textbf{amblanane}. | \gll ndï ilum moko-e \textbf{ambla}=na-n-e | \gls 3PL little take-DEP PL.REFL=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `They would share little [pieces] with each other.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï atuma wot ala mundu \textbf{moke} \textbf{amblanane}. | \gll ndï atuma wot ala mundu moko-e \textbf{ambla}=na-n-e | \gls 3PL older.brother younger PL.DIST food take-DEP PL.REFL=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `They, those brothers, shared the food.’

Knowledge Point: Also, although not necessarily common, it is possible for na- ‘give’ to follow a verb in the preceding clause that means something other than ‘take’. For example, the verb na- ‘give’ may follow the verbs wana- ‘cook’ \REF{ex:clause:47} or nïkï- ‘dig, cut’ \REF{ex:clause:48}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ma isi \textbf{wanap} yawa \textbf{lananda}. | \gll ma isi \textbf{wana}-p yawa ala=\textbf{na}-nda | \gls 3SG.OBJ soup cook-PFV uncle PL.DIST=give-IRR | \glt `[They] will cook her soup and give [it] to the uncles.’
Content 2: \gsrc An keka \textbf{mankap} \textbf{ndïnan}. | \gll an keka ma=\textbf{nïkï-}p ndï=\textbf{na}-n | \gls 1PL.EXCL completely 3SG.OBJ=dig-PFV 3PL=give-PFV | \glt `We butchered it and gave it out completely to them.’

Knowledge Point: While ‘giving’ is the prototypical event to be encoded by \isi{ditransitive} constructions (in languages that exhibit them), there are other verbs that are likely to function similarly crosslinguistically. In the remainder of this section I describe how ‘showing’ events are encoded in Ulwa. Whereas ‘giving’ events in Ulwa are encoded with two \isi{transitive} verbs (typically tï- ‘take’ and na- ‘give’), ‘showing’ events are encoded with a single \isi{intransitive} verb (si- ‘push’). In other contexts, this verb is used \isi{transitive}ly \REF{ex:clause:49}, often in conjunction with the verb lï- ‘put’, to covey the sense of something being pushed upon something else, as in \REF{ex:clause:50} and \REF{ex:clause:51}, or in conjunction with the preverbal form [ikali] (literally ‘hand-send’) to convey the act of grabbing, holding, or catching, as in \REF{ex:clause:52} and \REF{ex:clause:53}.\footnote{Like tï- ‘take’, si- ‘push’ is often \isi{defective} in that it commonly lacks \isi{perfective} or \isi{imperfective} \isi{aspect} marking.}
Content 1: \gsrc Ndin u itïtïl \textbf{ndïse}. | \gll ndï=in u itïtïl ndï=\textbf{si}-e | \gls 3PL=in from dust 3PL=push-IPFV | \glt `[I] was pushing the dust out from them.’
Content 2: \gsrc Unap \textbf{ndïs} apïn \textbf{lïp}. | \gll u=nap ndï=\textbf{si} apïn \textbf{lï}-p | \gls 2SG=for 3PL=push fire put-PFV | \glt `[They] put them on the fire for you.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nawoli mangusuwa imbake apa i wutï \textbf{si} \textbf{nimbamlïp}. | \gll Nawoli ma-ngusuwa imba-ka-e apa i wutï \textbf{si} nï=imbam-\textbf{lï}-p | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ{-}poor night-at-DEP house go.PFV leg push 1SG=under-put-PFV | \glt `Nawoli, the poor thing, came to [my] house at night and put [his] legs under me.’
Content 4: \gsrc Nungol mï \textbf{ikali} \textbf{mas}. | \gll nungol mï \textbf{i-kali} ma=\textbf{si} | \gls child 3SG.SUBJ hand-send 3SG.OBJ=push | \glt `The son grabbed it.’
Content 5: \gsrc U wa li mama \textbf{ikali masina}? | \gll u wa li ma=ma \textbf{i-kali} ma=\textbf{si}-na | \gls 2SG just down 3SG.OBJ=go hand-send 3SG.OBJ=push-IRR | \glt `You’ll just go down there and grab it?’

Knowledge Point: When used to encode a ‘showing’ event, however, the verb si- ‘push’ is \isi{intransitive}: the \isi{agent} (the one showing) is the subject of the verb; the \isi{theme} (that which is shown) is marked by the \isi{oblique marker} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’; and the \isi{experiencer} (the one to whom something is shown) is the object of the \isi{postposition} ul ‘with’. The preferred order of these two non-core arguments is for the \isi{oblique}-marked \isi{noun phrase} to precede the \isi{postpositional phrase}. Literally such sentences may be rendered as ‘[\isi{agent}] pushes with [\isi{theme}] (along) with [\isi{experiencer}]’. They may be seen in examples \REF{ex:clause:54} through \REF{ex:clause:58}.
Content 1: \gsrc Gwam mï tawa \textbf{man} Mapana \textbf{mol} \textbf{si}. | \gll Gwam mï tawa ma=\textbf{n} Mapana ma=\textbf{ul} si | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ wound 3SG.OBJ=OBL [name] 3SG.OBJ=with push | \glt `Gwam showed her wound to Mapana.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Man ndul si}. | \gll ma=\textbf{n} ndï=\textbf{ul} \textbf{si} | \gls 3SG.OBJ=OBL 3PL=with push | \glt `[He] showed it to them.’

Knowledge Point: The clearest illustrations of the position and function of obliques in Ulwa are NPs that contain the \isi{enclitic} form =n ‘\textsc{obl}’, which may be considered an \isi{oblique marker}. When following a \isi{noun phrase}, this oblique-marker \isi{enclitic} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ can be described as something like a non-core \isi{case marker}. It often encodes \isi{instrumental} functions, and may, in origin, be an \isi{instrumental} marker. Synchronically, however, it can serve other \isi{semantic} and grammatical functions, none of which relates to indicating a \isi{core argument}. The \isi{oblique marker} is realized by a set of similar \isi{allomorph}s, which are mostly in \isi{free variation} \REF{ex:clause:59}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In examples \REF{ex:clause:60} through \REF{ex:clause:65}, the \isi{oblique} NP marked by =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ appears after the subject (if expressed) and before the object of the verb.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom \textbf{napnï} uta masap. | \gll itom nap=\textbf{nï} uta ma=asa-p | \gls father arrow=OBL bird 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Father shot the bird with an arrow.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nïnji apa may nji \textbf{ndïn} apa up. | \gll nï-nji apa ma=i nji ndï=\textbf{n} apa u-p | \gls 1SG-POSS house 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV thing 3PL=OBL house put-PFV | \glt ‘[I] went to my house and put things in the house.’

Knowledge Point: Note the argument structure of the word glossed as ‘put’ in \REF{ex:clause:65}: the object of the verb is the place where the item is put; the \isi{theme} is expressed in the \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase} (cf. the argument structure of the \ili{English} verb load). Similarly, the word glossed as ‘tie’ in \REF{ex:clause:66} takes as object the thing to which something is tied; that which is tied is encoded in the \isi{oblique} \isi{phrase}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji apa may nji \textbf{ndïn} apa up. | \gll nï-nji apa ma=i nji ndï=\textbf{n} apa u-p | \gls 1SG-POSS house 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV thing 3PL=OBL house put-PFV | \glt ‘[I] went to my house and put things in the house.’
Content 2: \gsrc Lamndu nungol kosape an \textbf{man} im itap. | \gll lamndu nungol ko=asa-p-e an ma=\textbf{n} im ita-p | \gls pig child INDF=hit-PFV-DEP 1PL.EXCL 3SG.OBJ=OBL tree tie-PFV | \glt `[They] killed a small pig and we tied it to stick.’

Knowledge Point: Obliques may occur within \isi{compound verb} \isi{phrase}s or between verbs functioning together in complex \isi{verb phrase}s. Examples \REF{ex:clause:67} and \REF{ex:clause:68} illustrate non-\isi{instrumental} uses of the \isi{oblique marker}: in \REF{ex:clause:67} it has more of a \isi{comitative} meaning, whereas in \REF{ex:clause:68} it has more of a \isi{benefactive} meaning (see \sectref{sec:11.4.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc Wa ala lïmndï \textbf{unanï} mbu mawte. | \gll wa ala lïmndï unan=\textbf{nï} mbï-u ma=uta-e | \gls village PL.DIST eye 1PL.INCL=OBL here-from 3SG.OBJ=grind-IPFV | \glt `Those [people from other] villages see it here among us.’
Content 2: \gsrc Mint \textbf{ambïn} ani menlïp. | \gll min=tï ambï=\textbf{n} ani ma=in-lï-p | \gls 3DU=take SG.REFL=OBL bilum 3SG.OBJ=in-put-PFV | \glt `[I] put them into the bilum [= string bag] for myself.’
Content 3: \gsrc Wa ala lïmndï \textbf{unanï} mbu mawte. | \gll wa ala lïmndï unan=\textbf{nï} mbï-u ma=uta-e | \gls village PL.DIST eye 1PL.INCL=OBL here-from 3SG.OBJ=grind-IPFV | \glt `Those [people from other] villages see it here among us.’
Content 4: \gsrc Mint \textbf{ambïn} ani menlïp. | \gll min=tï ambï=\textbf{n} ani ma=in-lï-p | \gls 3DU=take SG.REFL=OBL bilum 3SG.OBJ=in-put-PFV | \glt `[I] put them into the bilum [= string bag] for myself.’

Knowledge Point: The oblique-marked NP may occur alongside other non-core elements in a clause, such as \isi{postpositional phrase}s. \isi{Postpositional phrase}s may either precede oblique-marked NPs -- as in \REF{ex:clause:69} and \REF{ex:clause:70} -- or follow them -- as in \REF{ex:clause:71} and \REF{ex:clause:72} -- but they always occur between subjects and objects.
Content 1: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mol apïnï} mame. | \gll nï \textbf{ma=ul} \textbf{apïn=nï} ma=ama-e | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=with fire=OBL 3SG.OBJ=eat-IPFV | \glt `I burn it with him.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï \textbf{mawl ndïn} mbup. | \gll nï \textbf{ma=ul} \textbf{ndï=n} mbï-u-p | \gls 1SG 3SG.OBJ=with 3PL=OBL here-put-PFV | \glt `I planted them here with him.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Ndïn} maka \textbf{ya ndiya} ata unde. | \gll \textbf{ndï=n} maka \textbf{ya} \textbf{ndï=iya} ata unda-e | \gls 3PL=OBL thus coconut 3PL=toward up go-IPFV | \glt `With them [= straps around their feet] [they] would go up coconut trees like that.’
Content 4: \gsrc Ala \textbf{nïn amba ngo} numbu lïp itana man. | \gll ala \textbf{nï=n} \textbf{amba} \textbf{nga=u} numbu lï-p it-ana ma-n | \gls PL.DIST 1SG=OBL mens.house SG.PROX=from post put-PFV build{-irr} go{-ipfv} | \glt `They are going to tie me to a post in this men’s house.’

Knowledge Point: The \isi{negator} ango ‘\textsc{neg}’ typically follows subjects (when expressed), but precedes any \isi{oblique} NPs, as in \REF{ex:clause:73}, \REF{ex:clause:74}, and \REF{ex:clause:75}.
Content 1: \gsrc U \textbf{ango inambanï} ini men. | \gll u \textbf{ango} \textbf{inamba=nï} ini ma=in | \gls 2SG NEG money=OBL ground 3SG.OBJ=get | \glt `You did not buy the land.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ango} maka \textbf{nginï} ute. | \gll \textbf{ango} maka \textbf{ngin=nï} uta-e | \gls NEG thus net=OBL grind-IPFV | \glt `[They] didn’t catch [fish] with the nets.’
Content 3: \gsrc \textbf{Ango man} ambi itanate. | \gll \textbf{ango} \textbf{ma=n} ambi ita-na-t-e | \gls NEG 3SG.OBJ=OBL big build-IRR-SPEC-DEP | \glt `[I] won’t build it [too] big.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:clause:75} also illustrates the preverbal placement of an \isi{adjective} when functioning \isi{adverb}ially (\sectref{sec:8.2.6}) and the effect of this on the \isi{semantic} object of the verb: it is \isi{demote}d to an \isi{oblique}, being marked by the \isi{oblique} marker =n ‘\textsc{obl}’. This phenomenon also occurs in \REF{ex:clause:76}, \REF{ex:clause:77}, and \REF{ex:clause:78}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ango man} ambi itanate. | \gll \textbf{ango} \textbf{ma=n} ambi ita-na-t-e | \gls NEG 3SG.OBJ=OBL big build-IRR-SPEC-DEP | \glt `[I] won’t build it [too] big.’
Content 2: \gsrc Ndï ango \textbf{ndïn anma} asap. | \gll ndï ango \textbf{ndï=n} \textbf{anma} asa-p | \gls 3PL NEG 3PL=OBL good hit-PFV | \glt `They did not kill them well.’
Content 3: \gsrc U mat inde \textbf{man anma} tï inde. | \gll u ma=tï inda-e \textbf{ma=n} \textbf{anma} tï inda-e | \gls 2SG 3SG.OBJ=take walk-DEP 3SG.OBJ=OBL good take walk-DEP | \glt `You carry her, carry her well.’
Content 4: \gsrc Apa mï ndï \textbf{man tembi} itap. | \gll apa mï ndï \textbf{ma=n} \textbf{tembi} ita-p | \gls house 3SG.SUBJ 3PL 3SG.OBJ=OBL bad build-PFV | \glt `The house -- they built it poorly.’

Subsection: The oblique marker as case marker\label{sec:11.4.2
Knowledge Point: As described in \sectref{sec:11.4.1}, the primary function of the oblique-marker \isi{enclitic} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ is to encode \isi{non-core NP}s. These oblique-marked NPs may serve a number of functions in a clause, many of which are reminiscent of \isi{case}-marked NPs in languages that employ grammatical \isi{case}. Specifically, the marker =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ has certain functions that resemble those of \isi{dative} markers found in other languages (although, importantly, it does not mark the \isi{recipient} in ‘giving’ constructions, \sectref{sec:11.3}). Three such \isi{dative}-like uses of =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ are listed in \REF{ex:clause:78a}.
Content 1: Not found

Subsection: The oblique marker as case marker\label{sec:11.4.2
Knowledge Point: The use of the \isi{enclitic} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ to encode \isi{possessor}s is discussed in \sectref{sec:9.1.5}.\footnote{Cf. the \isi{dative} of \isi{possession} in classical \ili{Latin}.} For the role of the \isi{enclitic} =n ‘\textsc{obl}’ in marking \isi{agent}s in \isi{passive} constructions, see \sectref{sec:13.7}.\footnote{Cf. the \isi{dative} of the \isi{agent} in ancient \ili{Greek}.} In examples \REF{ex:clause:79}, \REF{ex:clause:80}, and \REF{ex:clause:81}, the \isi{oblique marker} indicates \isi{disadvantage}.\footnote{Cf. the \isi{dative} of \isi{disadvantage} in \ili{Latin}, \ili{Greek}, \ili{German}, etc.}
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{unan} mawat pe wombïn ne. | \gll mï unan=\textbf{n} ma=wat p-e wombïn=n ni-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 1PL.INCL=OBL 3SG.OBJ=atop be{-dep} work=OBL act-IPFV | \glt `He is hurting us by doing work during it [= this period of mourning].’
Content 2: \gsrc Tembi nji ngala apan \textbf{ndïn} mbïlïp. | \gll tembi nji ngala apa=n ndï=\textbf{n} mbï-lï-p | \gls bad thing PL.PROX house=OBL 3PL=OBL here-put-PFV | \glt `These bad things [= flies] have put [their] house [i.e., nest] here to their disadvantage.’
Content 3: \gsrc Ndï mokum \textbf{anïn} wandam pe ndam! | \gll ndï mokum an=\textbf{ïn} wandam p-e ndï=ama | \gls 3PL stealth 1PL.EXCL=OBL jungle be{-dep} 3PL=eat | \glt `They are stealthily in [our] jungles, eating them [= our crops]!’

Subsection: The oblique marker as case marker\label{sec:11.4.2
Knowledge Point: Sometimes, as in example \REF{ex:clause:81}, it is not clear whether the \isi{oblique marker} is encoding a \isi{possessor} or the experiencer of some \isi{disadvantage}. In \REF{ex:clause:82}, the oblique-marked NP indicating \isi{disadvantage} stands in its own \isi{embedded clause}, taking as its \isi{predicate} the \isi{locative verb} p- ‘be’.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndï mokum \textbf{anïn} wandam pe ndam! | \gll ndï mokum an=\textbf{ïn} wandam p-e ndï=ama | \gls 3PL stealth 1PL.EXCL=OBL jungle be{-dep} 3PL=eat | \glt `They are stealthily in [our] jungles, eating them [= our crops]!’
Content 2: \gsrc Ala \textbf{anïn pe} ndïwale. | \gll ala an=\textbf{ïn} p-e ndï=wali-e | \gls PL.DIST 1PL.EXCL=OBL be{-dep} 3PL=hit-IPFV | \glt `People were killing them [= our dogs], while we were there suffering for it.’

Subsection: The oblique marker as case marker\label{sec:11.4.2
Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:clause:83}, the \isi{dative} of \isi{disadvantage} usage of the \isi{oblique marker} has an almost predicative sense.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïpokonampïta \textbf{un} mapïna. | \gll nïpokonam=p-ta u=\textbf{n} ma=p-na | \gls hard=COP{-cond} 2SG=OBL 3SG.OBJ=be-IRR | \glt `If [the soil] is hard, [it] will be no good for you.’

Knowledge Point: Other non-core elements (namely, \isi{adverb}s and \isi{adpositional phrase}s) also typically occur between subjects and objects. For examples of this SXOV \isi{word order}, see \sectref{sec:8.1} (on \isi{postposition}s) and \sectref{sec:8.2} (on \isi{adverb}s). When a clause contains both an \isi{adverb} and an \isi{adpositional phrase}, the \isi{adverb} typically precedes the \isi{adpositional phrase}, as in \REF{ex:clause:84}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï \textbf{awal wandam mo} lop. | \gll mï \textbf{awal} \textbf{wandam} \textbf{ma=u} lo-p | \gls 3SG.SUBJ yesterday jungle 3SG.OBJ=from go{-pfv} | \glt `Yesterday, he went around in jungle.’

Knowledge Point: It is possible for several obliques to occur in succession, as in \REF{ex:clause:85}, which contains a \isi{temporal adverb}, an oblique-marked NP, a \isi{postposition}, and a \isi{modal adverb}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un \textbf{amun man u maka} wombïn ngamokop. | \gll un \textbf{amun} \textbf{ma=n} \textbf{u} \textbf{maka} wombïn nga=moko-p | \gls 2PL now 3SG.OBJ=OBL from thus work SG.PROX=take{-pfv} | \glt `You recently got this work from him.’

Knowledge Point: While Ulwa generally maintains a fairly rigid and unified distinction between S/A arguments and P arguments, there is one known construction that exhibits an unusual argument structure. In expressions of experiencing hunger, the \isi{experiencer} role is not the grammatical subject but is rather the object of the verb, whereas ‘hunger’ itself is the grammatical subject. In other words, there is a special \isi{case frame} for expressing the experience of hunger, which takes the form of ‘hunger hits someone’ (as opposed to, say, ‘someone is hungry’ or ‘someone has hunger’). This is illustrated by examples \REF{ex:clause:86}, \REF{ex:clause:87}, and \REF{ex:clause:88}.\footnote{It should be noted that the form mundu ‘hunger’ also means ‘food’ or ‘animal’.}
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Mundu} \textbf{unanas}. | \gll \textbf{mundu} unan=\textbf{asa} | \gls hunger 1PL.INCL=hit | \glt `We’re hungry.’
Content 2: \gsrc An mbïlop wop \textbf{mundu} \textbf{anase}. | \gll an mbï-lo-p wo-p \textbf{mundu} an-\textbf{asa}-e | \gls 1PL.EXCL here-go-PFV sleep-PFV hunger 1PL.EXCL-hit-IPFV | \glt `We came here, spent the night, and we were hungry.’

Knowledge Point: Although the \isi{experiencer} is always encoded as the object of the verb, it is common for it also to be included as an additional subject argument, as in \REF{ex:clause:89} and \REF{ex:clause:90}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nï} ango mundu \textbf{nïwale}. | \gll \textbf{nï} ango mundu \textbf{nï}=wali-e | \gls 1SG NEG hunger 1SG=hit-IPFV | \glt `I wasn’t hungry.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï ndïn ka mata \textbf{ndï} mundu \textbf{ndatïna}. | \gll nï ndï=n ka ma-ta \textbf{ndï} mundu \textbf{ndï}=atï-na | \gls 1SG 3PL=OBL let go-COND 3PL hunger 3PL=hit-IRR | \glt `If I leave them and go, they will be hungry.’

Knowledge Point: When the \isi{experiencer} is a full NP, it is common to include this argument in subject position -- that is, before the grammatical subject of the verb ‘hit’ (i.e., before the noun mundu ‘hunger’). The \isi{object marker}, however, which refers to the \isi{experiencer} argument, occurs in object position, \isi{clitic}izing to the verb, as in \REF{ex:clause:91}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji nungolke ngala} mundu \textbf{ndasape}. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} \textbf{nungolke} \textbf{ngala} mundu \textbf{ndï}=asa-p-e | \gls 1SG-POSS child PL.PROX hunger 3PL=hit-PFV-DEP | \glt `My children were hungry.’

Knowledge Point: Occasionally a verb other than ‘hit’ is used in expressing hunger, as in \REF{ex:clause:92}, which uses the verb a- ‘break’ (i.e., ‘hunger is breaking us’).
Content 1: \gsrc Unan mbïpe mane \textbf{mundu} \textbf{unanay}. | \gll unan mbï-p-e ma-n-e \textbf{mundu} unan=\textbf{a}-e | \gls 1PL.INCL here-be-DEP go-IPFV-DEP hunger 1PL.INCL-break-IPFV | \glt `But we are going around here and hunger is breaking us.’

Knowledge Point: Aside from this one hunger construction, there does not seem to be a robust \isi{morphosyntactic} distinction made in Ulwa between \isi{predicate}s expressing \isi{controlled} events and \isi{predicate}s expressing \isi{uncontrolled} events or states. Other expressions of physical or emotional states, such as pain, sickness, anger, and sadness, are not expressed with the \isi{experiencer} as the grammatical object, as is done for expressions of hunger. For example, pain is usually expressed by predicating apïn ‘pain’ (literally ‘fire’) of the person or body part that is experiencing pain \REF{ex:clause:93}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nïnji uma ngala \textbf{apïnpe}. | \gll nï-nji uma ngala \textbf{apïn}=p-e | \gls 1SG-POSS bone PL.PROX fire=COP-DEP | \glt `These bones of mine were hurting.’

Knowledge Point: Anger may be expressed by predicating the \isi{adjective} matamal ‘sharp; difficult, angry’ of the person experiencing anger \REF{ex:clause:94}.
Content 1: \gsrc Itom mï \textbf{matamalp}. | \gll itom mï \textbf{matamal}=p | \gls father 3SG.SUBJ sharp=COP | \glt `Father is angry.’

Knowledge Point: More commonly, however, anger is expressed by means of a verbal expression with uni- ‘shout’. In \REF{ex:clause:95}, the literal expression ‘shout for [something]’ or ‘shout on account of [something]’ conveys the meaning ‘be angry about [something]’. In \REF{ex:clause:96}, the literal expression ‘shout with [someone]’ conveys the meaning ‘be angry with [someone]’.
Content 1: \gsrc Mï ndïnap \textbf{unipe}. | \gll mï ndï=nap \textbf{uni}-p-e | \gls 3SG.SUBJ 3PL=for shout-PFV-DEP | \glt `She was angry about them [= seeds].’
Content 2: \gsrc We nï mol \textbf{une}. | \gll we nï ma=ul \textbf{uni}-e | \gls then 1SG 3SG.OBJ=with shout-IPFV | \glt `Then I got angry with her.’
